46.text:
The Kobelco 7250S is the top of the range
Kobelco crawler crane and it has a maximum

51.text:
lifting capacity of 250 tonnes. Inside the
outer shipping carton is a Kobelco branded

57.text:
box, and that contains three layers of expanded
polystyrene trays containing the many parts.

64.text:
In the top tray there is a set of brochures
and we will have a look at those in a moment.

68.text:
In the top layer there are a number of lattice
boom sections, and going down into the second

73.text:
layer there is more of the same. The bottom
layer has the crawler tracks and body. One

79.text:
of the very nice aspects of this model is
the inclusion of three brochures. The first

84.text:
is the general marketing brochure for Kobelco
crawler cranes and it has got some interesting

89.text:
information and photos. The second one we
are looking at is the manual for assembly

94.text:
of the model. It has got a full parts list
and it is helped by also having the bags in

99.text:
the box individually labelled. The instructions
are comprehensive and there are step by step

103.text:
photos. The last brochure in the box is technical
for the 7250S and it includes all of the load

110.text:
charts for the real crane. All of this means
the presentation of the model is very good.

120.text:
To start the assembly we will insert the jacks
into what is called the 'translifters' and

125.text:
these are just a simple screw-in attachment.
There are four of them and if you want the

130.text:
crane to stand on its own four feet then you
need to insert some pins to keep the legs

135.text:
in position. Once that is done we can add
the two ballast blocks to the carbody but

141.text:
they are not an easy fit because of a clash
due to paint thicknesses, and once in place

145.text:
you pin them in position. Next up this crane
likes to run around so lets give it some crawler

150.text:
tracks to do that. Each frame gets offered
up and then a couple of pins secure it in

155.text:
position. One nice touch on the model is that
there are travel clamps on the gantry and

161.text:
you remove these by undoing the nuts and bolts
using the special tools provided. All it then

166.text:
needs is a tug to free up any stickiness in
the paintwork. To raise the gantry you need

171.text:
to remove an elastic band, and just imagine
how you would get that off if they used the

176.text:
same thing on the real crane! The gantry is
now being raised and you can see why it does

181.text:
need to fold because if it is being transported
the crane would be too tall otherwise. Now

186.text:
that it is up you secure it using some more
nuts and bolts and we can move on to adding

191.text:
the counterweight tray at the rear. It hangs
in position and is pinned and you need to

195.text:
use pliers unless you have got fingers the
thickness of chopsticks. Actually if you do

199.text:
have fingers like that it must be really easy
to eat Chinese food. Anyway enough of the

205.text:
nonsense, lets move on and load up the counterweight
ad the big blocks just rest in place, which

209.text:
does mean they can be dislodged. Moving to
the front we are attaching the boom foot,

214.text:
but again because of tolerances and paint
thicknesses it takes some work to get it in

218.text:
position and then you insert a big pin to
secure it. So that is the main work done on

223.text:
the crane body to get it ready to be assembled,
and for this part of the review we will just

228.text:
set it up with a main boom. The lattice sections
are all nicely made and they include internal

233.text:
bracing, and they join together reasonably
easily and they are secured with more little

237.text:
nuts and bolts. There are plenty of guy ropes
that have to be made up too, and these are

242.text:
all joined together by more nuts and bolts,
but before we go nut and bolt crazy lets unwrap

247.text:
the luffing gear. This is pre-reeved in the
factory which is a help, but you have to be

252.text:
careful how you unwrap it to make sure you
keep the tension on the pulleys. If you do

256.text:
let the thread jump of the pulleys you are
definitely in for some frustration getting

260.text:
it back on. Here we have raised up the boom
so we can connect the end of the guy ropes

265.text:
to the luffing bridle. The next step is a
bit unusual - we have to attach the thread

270.text:
from the luffing fly jib onto the main winch
drum. There is no natural tying-off point,

274.text:
so the best way to do it is with a piece of
clear tape stuck on the end of the thread.

278.text:
It is much less messy than glue and it is
easily removable if you want to take the thread

283.text:
off, and it is also quite secure once you
have wound the winch drum a few times. If

287.text:
you are not using the luffing fly jib then
the luffing bridle clips onto the boom in

292.text:
a slightly unusual way. So here we are with
the boom up and we have now reeved on the

297.text:
70 tonne hook, and included with the model
is an I-beam load which you can put on the

301.text:
hook to give it some more tension. To finish
off this part of the assembly we just need

306.text:
to add on some detail and that includes steps
on each of the four corners of the crawler

311.text:
tracks, and there are plenty of walkways and
handrails to add. Most of these are a good

317.text:
fit but some of them you have to fiddle with
to get them to stay in place properly. There

321.text:
is a neat little cover which goes over the
access point to the rear winch and there is

325.text:
another cover which goes over the front two
winches.

346.text:
For the detail we will start with the crawler
tracks and the metal pads are nicely formed,

350.text:
and the track frames are fairly simple without
working rollers. The cab is very detailed

355.text:
and there are some tiny graphics, and another
hot detail.... is this hot detail. All of the

361.text:
pulleys used on the model are metal, and there
is a high standard of detailing on the lattice

366.text:
sections including tiny graphics. Most of
the boom sections also include mesh walkways.

373.text:
On the tower cap most of the connections are
bolted so you can flatten things for transport,

379.text:
and the little white wind gauge adds to the
realism. At the boom top there are more metal

384.text:
pulleys and some tiny holes that are tying-off
points. Three metal hooks are supplied and

398.text:
Lets start by having a look at the crawler
tracks, and they are free-rolling on both

401.text:
of the frames and they are tensioned by sprig-loaded
idlers. One of the features of a model like

407.text:
this though is that if you do not want to
build it up you can use the parts as transport

411.text:
loads, so here the tracks are going on to
a Nooteboom trailer, or as an alternative

416.text:
we can load up some boom sections. One thing
you can do with the model is to pretend to

421.text:
drive it like a real crane, but you can expect
it to wear out your wrist action. So far we

427.text:
have only assembled the model with a modest
main boom, but there are plenty more main

431.text:
boom sections we can add in, and we can also
put it into a tower configuration by adding

437.text:
in the optional luffing fly jib. And here
we have it all pre-assembled ready to add

442.text:
on to the model. Once you have it all built
up then you can display it with the luffing

447.text:
fly jib clipped to the boom, but one thing
you cannot do is lower the angle too much

452.text:
because it will be unstable and there is not
enough thread on the boom drums. Still there

457.text:
is enough thread for the luffing jib and you
can winch that up into position. One thing

462.text:
to note is that the guy ropes are not all
exactly the same length so you might need

465.text:
to swap some spares to maintain equal tension.
Now that we have built the full model lets

470.text:
see how high it goes, and it is about 70 inches
or nearly 180 centimetres.

496.text:
This is another very detailed Kobelco crane
model by Tonkin Replicas. It is well presented

502.text:
and is flexible with many different configurations
being possible, and most of the features work

507.text:
well enough with just a few restrictions,
but certainly a plus point is the very high

511.text:
detail level, and that makes it an outstanding
model.
